Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Kevin Messenger of Alabama A & M University to conduct a research project, entitled "Dietary preferences of Red-necked keelback snakes and the implications of using defensive toxins," during the summer of 2012 at Beijing Normal University in Beijing, Beijing Province, China. The host scientist is Dr. Zhang Zhengwang at Beijing Normal University, as well as Dr. Liang Wei and Dr. Shi Haitao of Hainan Normal University.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is looking at the largely unknown genus of snakes known as Rhabdophis, which are one of the very few genera in the world that is both poisonous and venomous. Work on this genus is nearly non-existent with the exception of one species from the islands of Japan. Results contribute significantly to the understanding and evolutionary position of this little known, and unique genus.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of my project were not as originally planned. My original plan was to look at the dietary preferences and defensive behavior of an endemic keelback snake on Hainan Island, Rhabdophis adleri, the Hainan Keelback. However, the species ended up being quite uncommon in the summer months. Most locals say they see it in the spring. I searched for my target species for the 6 weeks the program in was in session, but at the same time working on a backup plan. The backup plan, which I was able to do simultaneously while looking for my target species was a simple inventory of the reptiles and amphibians at the various nature reserves where we were searching for my target species.

My team and I ended up cataloging the reptiles and amphibians of three different national nature reserves in Hainan Island in southern China. Hainan Island is the only tropical island in China and is toted as “China’s Hawaii.” The island is very mountainous and the mountains in the middle of the island divide the climate into two distinct regions. On the north side of the island the climate is considered sub-tropical, whereas the south side is considered tropical. We surveyed one reserve on the northeast corner of the island called Tong Gu Ling. Another reserve location centrally was called Li Mu Shan, and then finally the last reserve was south central and it was called Diao Luo Shan. Diao Luo Shan was the highest of the reserves at about 900 meters in elevation.

Two of the reserves had never been sampled before, so any species we found essentially became a new record for that nature reserve. During the study period, we documented 21 species of snakes, 8 species of lizards, 1 species of salamander, and 24 species of frogs.

I am working with another professor in Hong Kong who did a survey of Diao Luo Shan back in the mid-1990’s. We are going to combine our data and put out a revised herpetofaunal list with updated data. While we surveyed Diao Luo Shan we found a few species that they did not record in the 1990’s.
